metadata.synopsis: Gale re-examines his position re: exploding.

12.speaker: Narrator
12.text: *Another restless night beckons. Your mind flits from memory to memory, the deeds you've done and left undone in the wake of Mystra's instruction.*
12.context: CinematicNodeContext: Gale lies on his bed roll, restless

50.speaker: Narrator
50.text: *Her presence haunts your every decision - the ones she would endorse, and those she would disdain. Defy her doctrines while she watches, and you would not be merely disobedient. You would be dangerous.*

16.speaker: Narrator
16.text: *Though the night is still, your heart feels quite the opposite. Elminster's letter has given you much to digest.*
16.context: CinematicNodeContext: Gale lies on his bed roll, restless

59.speaker: Narrator
59.text: *Can it really be true? Does he believe Mystra's instruction is wrong?*

34.speaker: Gale
34.text: He defies Mystra himself in saying so. He wouldn't do that without good reason.

25.speaker: Narrator
25.text: *In all the years you've known Elminster, he's never once questioned his goddess' wisdom. For him to do so now... there must be something to this.*

13.speaker: Gale
13.text: Elminster's an enigma. Who knows what games he's playing.

0.speaker: Narrator
0.text: *None can truly know what goes on beneath Elminster's tattered old hat. Just because he has centuries worth of wisdom, doesn't mean he's direct, or honest, in sharing it.*

46.speaker: Narrator
46.text: *You finally appear to be winning back Mystra's favour, even her blessings. But appearances are not everything, and after all - she does not give without expecting in return.*

19.speaker: Gale
19.text: She gives what she can. And you receive her aid gratefully.

35.speaker: Narrator
35.text: *It brings you comfort, knowing that Mystra's hand rests on your shoulder. Though she remains aloof, she does not send you to your fate alone.*

33.speaker: Narrator
33.text: *Are you truly ready to sacrifice yourself for her?*

40.speaker: Gale
40.text: No. If Elminster believes there's another way, so do you.

45.speaker: Narrator
45.text: *Mystra's conclusion is based on a flawed assumption. The orb cannot be the only means of destroying the Absolute, though she may think it the most convenient.*

27.speaker: Narrator
27.text: *What that alternative may be, you have yet to discover. But you will discover it. Whether Mystra wants you to or not.*

60.speaker: Gale
60.text: You'll die on nobody's orders. Especially not hers.

57.speaker: Narrator
57.text: *Mystra has forgotten how carefully mortals tend to their brief and fragile lives. And what lengths they will go to to protect them.*

32.speaker: Narrator
32.text: *You may yet have cause to remind her.*

30.speaker: Gale
30.text: Not for her, but for everyone else.

3.speaker: Narrator
3.text: *Mystra's fate is none of your concern. But you will not allow mortal innocents to die by the Absolute's hand. Not when it lies in your power to prevent it.*

6.speaker: Narrator
6.text: *If the orb is the only way to ensure victory, you'll have no choice but to use it.*

37.speaker: Narrator
37.text: *Your resolve is steady. It is not just Mystra you save with your sacrifice. Faerûn itself depends on you.*

15.speaker: Gale
15.text: Her gifts have their uses, but she still leaves the hard work to you.

64.speaker: Narrator
64.text: *If the Heart of the Absolute is within reach, it's not because of her intervention. It's because of your efforts. Your struggle. Your life being put on the line.*

52.speaker: Gale
52.text: She forced her favours upon you. You owe her nothing.

66.speaker: Narrator
66.text: *Your obedience cannot be guaranteed by such piecemeal rewards as Mystra deigns to give.*

2.speaker: Gale
2.text: Useless trifles. She still keeps the Weave's true power for herself.

51.speaker: Narrator
51.text: *Perhaps these favours are intended to appease you. To make you hunger for the even greater reward she will bestow if you continue to obey.*

9.speaker: Narrator
9.text: *She offers you only the chance, the hope of redemption. Would you really give your life on such flimsy promises?*

26.speaker: Gale
26.text: Impossible. Elminster's utterly devoted to her.

44.speaker: Narrator
44.text: *Elminster's life has been spent in unwavering service to Mystra. He worships her devoutly, as you once did. So why would he plant such doubts in you now?*

41.speaker: Gale
41.text: It could be sabotage, an attempt to deny you your chance at redemption...

39.speaker: Narrator
39.text: *Mystra chose you for this task, not Elminster. Could jealousy lie at the heart of his insistence that you intentionally fail in your duty?*

22.speaker: Narrator
22.text: *Though the shadow magic you consumed is nothing compared to your old mastery of the Weave, it is novel. Exciting. And in Mystra's eyes, dangerous.*

48.speaker: Gale
48.text: She has no right to interfere. You don't answer to her.

21.speaker: Narrator
21.text: *That you still live and breathe is a miracle in itself. A sign that Mystra may be unwilling to directly intervene.*

54.speaker: Narrator
54.text: *Or is her silence merely the hope that you may yet follow the self-destructive path she desires, without the need to force your hand?*

17.speaker: Gale
17.text: Dangerous or not, you need all the help you can get.

23.speaker: Narrator
23.text: *Though the powers you gained are not savoury in their origin, that will matter little if they keep you, and the orb, in one piece.*

5.speaker: Gale
5.text: You've been indulging yourself. No harm in that.

4.speaker: Narrator
4.text: *Following your curiosity, wielding unknown magic... You feel more like yourself than you have in months. And who knows how long your 'self' has left?*

53.speaker: Narrator
53.text: *Each day brings you closer to finding the Heart of the Absolute. The source of Mystra's fear. And, for you, perhaps her forgiveness...*

18.speaker: Gale
18.text: She's going to be disappointed. You've no intention of dying.

20.speaker: Gale
20.text: You'll learn more about the Heart. Only then will you decide.

56.speaker: Narrator
56.text: *You would not simply destroy something so valuable. To do so would be foolish, irresponsible even.*

38.speaker: Narrator
38.text: *You must learn more about the Heart of the Absolute. After all, such power could come in useful, in the right hands.*

63.speaker: Gale
63.text: You will destroy the Absolute. Not for her, but for everyone else.

47.speaker: Gale
47.text: You will reward her faith in you. When the time comes, you will be ready.

58.speaker: Gale
58.text: She might be right. You've drawn powers from a grim source.

55.speaker: Narrator
55.text: *The magic you called on will have its uses, but you can't shake the feeling you lost something of yourself in the bargain.*

14.speaker: Narrator
14.text: *Still, there is time yet to set your course straight. All may be forgiven, if you serve her as Elminster instructed.*

31.speaker: Narrator
31.text: *For the first time since the orb sank its claws into your chest, you feel your pulse quicken with a familiar sensation.*
31.context: CinematicNodeContext: Gale lies on his bed roll, restless

42.speaker: Narrator
42.text: *In crafting the shadow lantern, you recaptured a taste of what you once had - the power to create, to compel, to imagine. It was exhilarating. And in Mystra's eyes, dangerous.*

67.speaker: Narrator
67.text: *You try to rest, but the tadpole within you has other plans. It writhes and stretches, comfortable within your skull. As comfortable as you've become wielding it.*

11.speaker: Narrator
11.text: *Even at the height of your powers, you'd never have dreamed of commanding such a creature, or using its will to amplify your own. It's exhilirating, and in Mystra's eyes, dangerous.*
